bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 30, 1900

div1.p: Reed's baggage has to be disinfected for “Yellow Jack” before he leaves for the States. He believes this to be an absurd formality. Reed wants to install a shower at the renovated Keewaydin house.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 30, 1900
div1.opener:
Camp Columbia,
Quemados, Cuba,
July 30th 1900
No. 27-
Monday night.
My precious wifie;
div1.p:
I packed
my trunk, this afternoon,
and took it to Havana, in
order to have it & its con-
tents thoroughly disinfec-
ted preparatory to board-
ing the Transport, Raw-
lins, on Wednesday- You
never saw anything like
the care with which every
piece of wearing apparel
is subjected to steam or
Formalin, for fear that
Yellow Jack may be con-
veyed to the United States-
of course, it was absurd
to disinfect my baggage, but
no exceptions are made-
Wednesday morning the con-
tents of my valise will
also be put in the big
sterilizer- The Quarterm-
aster told me, this afternoon
that the Rawlins would be
here Tuesday afternoon, &
would leave either Wed-
nesday evening or Thursday
morning- So that the chances
of getting away August 1st
or 2nd are very good- If
we leave on Thursday, 2nd
we will reach N.Y. Monday,
6th & be held over in quar-
antine till Tuesday afternoon
the 7th- This would enable me
to reach Keewaydin on Wed-
nesday, 8th- of course, I will
telegraph when we reach N.Y,
As my precious oomsey won't
get this till Monday next (as
it can't go till Wednesday the
1st,) I shouldn't be surprised
if you got a telegram on the
same day announcing our
arrival in New York- Your
precious letter of the 25th
came this morning- Another
rain, sweetheart! two
more rains? How per-
fectly delightful! I know
that you have been made
more than glad to see the
poor thirsty plants & veg-
etables turning green
again- The news about
the water-melons simply
charms me! If we only
get a good season from
this on, I think that we can
depend on that patch
bringing forth something
very toothsome! Am so
glad to hear that the last
corn will succeed- Surely
Mr Happle will have a plenty
of corn to supply your wants --
till that comes in -- nothing
is more delicious with
good fried chicken! and
hot waffles for breakfast! My!!!
Tuesday morning. 31st. After visions
of chicken & waffles, I simply had
to turn into bed so as to hurry
Tuesday along as much as possible.
Those pansies that my darling
wifie sent me were very
sweet and pretty, and I ap-
preciated them so much- But
I am more anxious to see them
with my own eyes as they
grow at dear Keewaydin.
Tomorrow or next day, I
shall begin my homeward
sea-voyage, and I hope
without being very sick, es-
pecially as the sea has been
so quiet this summer-
Here Mr Ramon Fong comes
in to say, “Good morning, dotter”!
and his small eyes fairly dance!
He has turned out to be
Chinese and not Japanese
as we had supposed- Isn't
it funny that we should have
all been so fooled by his looks!
He is as bright and smart as
can be & is learning English
very fast- I am teaching & cor-
recting him every day- He no lon-
ger says “bom bye”, but “after
a leetle while”!) It's very funny
to hear him talk- Knows lots
of spanish & rattles off chinese
like a steam engine- Save a little
of the mint for me, dearest, and
have an extra supply of old
Crow on hand by August 8th.
How delighted I am at the thought
of seeing my precious babies again.
Love to Sis Mottsey- Love and kisses
for my precious wifie & Daughter -- Devotedly,
Papa.

The Trans-
port hadn't arrived at half
past five, last evening, al-
though it was expected at
any time- It is not yet seven six
o'clock & hence too early to
find out by telephone
whether she came in du-
ring the night- I shall
go down, this morning, to
Havana, with my valise
to find out more definitely-
If she is there I shall leave
my valise at the disin-
fecting station- It seems that
the Rawlins had to go first
to Matanzas, & this delayed
her arrival at Havana,
It is one of those genuine
United States rainy morn-
ings, such as I have not seens
in Cuba before- Looks as
if it would rain all day
long- Just a good steady
though somewhat gentle,
downpour- The kind of
day that one will need
an umbrella & fortunately
I have one- I am expecting
several sweet letters
from my darling children
this morning, and hence I am
wishing that the mail-man
would hurry up. Yesterday
I took it very slowly, es-
pecially as the bromide
had made me so very sleepy.
I lay down after lunch and
slept till four o'clock, and
got up still feeling sleepy,
My shower-bath, this morning,
has helped me to get awake,
I don't think, sweetheart,
that there ever was such
an institution as a good
shower-bath -- not overhead,
but the spray coming from
the side so that your head
doesn't get wet at all.
You can depend upon it that
the enlarged & completed
Keewaydin is going to have
one, if we can get together
enough money to put up
the fixtures -- and I think that
we can- I will now hurry
this short letter to an end
and if I can write another
note from Havana to go
off before 12 o'clock, I
will do so- I think that No.
27 will be the last letter
for the present- Unless there
should be some delay at this
end of the line. If we don't go
until tomorrow, I may write a short
note that can follow me- Boo! Boo!
you precious joy- Love to aunt Jane. Kiss
Fat joy 20 times for me- Kisses & love for my
babies.
